aavfwp01 - HP-UX B.11.31 System Documentation

Created 2012-03-01 01:15:04 with cfg2html/HP-UX version 5.13

To use advanced features like CSS and screen tips we recommend to use MS IE 5+, FireFox/Mozilla or Opera 7+

cfg2html home page: http://come.to/cfg2html or www.cfg2html.com, for my HP internal web page, see doc/cfg2html.html

Quick System Overview



Hostname           aavfwp01
Model              ia64 hp server BL870c

Software ID        USE843H8NK  (not available on every machine)
# CPUs (Cores)    
# Disks            Total =
Memory              GB
Deviceswap         24.000 GB
Memory swapable    22.797 GB

HP-UX/System

Model

PrintModel
Modelstring:    ia64 hp server BL870c (no description)
Number of CPUs: 4
CPU capable:    64 bits
CPU Speed:      399 MHz

uname and hostname

HostNames
HP-UX aavfwp01 B.11.31 U ia64 0364881987 unlimited-user license
HP-UX 32/64 = 64 bits

Domainname  = 
Hostname    = aavfwp01

POSIX Standards/Settings

posixversion
POSIX Version:  200112
POSIX Version:  200112
X/OPEN Version: 600
LANG setting:   C
Time Zone (TZ): EST5EDT

Locale

locale
LANG=C
LC_CTYPE="C"
LC_COLLATE="C"
LC_MONETARY="C"
LC_NUMERIC="C"

LC_ALL=

init:4:initdefault:
utm1::sysinit:> /etc/utmp      # Clear current logon accounting file
utm2::sysinit:> /etc/utmpx     # Clear current logon accounting file
ioin::sysinit:/sbin/ioinitrc >/dev/console 2>&1
tape::sysinit:/sbin/mtinit > /dev/console 2>&1
muxi::sysinit:/sbin/dasetup   /dev/console 2>&1 # mux init
stty::sysinit:/sbin/stty 9600 clocal icanon echo opost onlcr ixon icrnl ignpar  /dev/null 2>&1  # kill fsdaemon
fs02:123456:respawn:/sbin/fs/fsdaemon -f 0 > /dev/null 2>&1  # start fsdaemon
fs03::wait:/sbin/fs/fsdaemon -t > /dev/null 2>&1  # Wait for fsdaemon to start
vxen::bootwait:/sbin/fs/vxfs/vxenablef -a
brc1::bootwait:/sbin/bcheckrc /dev/console 2>&1 # fsck, etc.
link::wait:/sbin/sh -c "/sbin/rm -f /dev/syscon; \
                        /sbin/ln /dev/systty /dev/syscon" >/dev/console 2>&1
cprt::bootwait:/sbin/cat /etc/copyright >/dev/syscon           # legal req
sqnc::wait:/sbin/rc /dev/console 2>&1           # system init
#powf::powerwait:/sbin/powerfail >/dev/console 2>&1            # powerfail

ioscan -m hwpath

FROM HP_DeviceIndication WHERE ProviderName = "CoreHardwareIndicationProviderIA" UNKNOWN

FROM HP_DeviceIndication WHERE ProviderName = "MemoryIndicationProviderIA"       UNKNOWN                                
HPWEBES_ftwp1cvhvfa01.northcentralnetworks.com_0_Filter_HP_AlertIndication HPWEBES_ftwp1cvhvfa01.northcentralnetworks.com_0_Handler_HP_AlertIndication select * 
from HP_AlertIndication                                                          UNKNOWN

At least there must be a HP* and a WEBES* subscription for communication with HP-SIM

Disk Firmware Collect with Hardware Path

/opt/cfg2html/plugins/firmware_collect.sh
Hardwarepath                   Device    Vendor/Product        Cap/GB Firm.  QD IR 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
QD = SCSI queue depth (0=no hw/medium), IR = immediate reporting (0=off, 1=on)

Serial Attached SCSI (SAS) Mass Storage

/opt/cfg2html/plugins/get_sasinfo.sh
Class        I  H/W Path  Driver S/W State   H/W Type     Description
====================================================================
escsi_ctlr   0  0/2/1/0   sasd   CLAIMED     INTERFACE    HP  PCI/PCI-X SAS MPT Adapter
                         /dev/sasd0
---= /dev/sasd0 ====
Driver Name                                        : sasd                
Bundle Version                                     : B.11.31.02          
Product Number                                     : AH232-60001         
Hardware Path                                      : 0/2/1/0             
Health of HBA                                      : ONLINE              
PCI Vendor ID                                      : 0x1000              
PCI Device ID                                      : 0x0054              
PCI Subsystem Vendor ID                            : 0x103c

Unconfigured/Corrupted Software

swlist -a state -l fileset | grep -v -e configured -e ^#
  VParProvider.VPAR-RUN                         installed

1.) Hint: man swverify, man swconfig to reconfigure corrupted software! swmodify -u PHxx_##### to remove patch references

2.) Hint: man check_patches (HP-UX 11.xx);; swlist -a state -l fileset | grep -v -e configured -e ^# | awk '{print ;}'|xargs swconfig

Gurus only: swlist -l fileset - state | grep installed | awk '{print ;}'>/tmp/sw.tmp; swmodify -a state=configured -f /tmp/sw.tmp

These useful tools are not delivered with HP-UX core, but as a patch: PHCO_27780 (or newer) for HP-UX 11.11 (replaces PHCO_24630) Use cleanup under HP-UX 10.20 and cleanup -c 1 under 11.xx

Mountpoints (fstab)

cat /etc/fstab|grep -v '^#'
/dev/vgroot/lvroot / vxfs delaylog 0 1
/dev/vgroot/lvstand /stand vxfs tranflush 0 1
/dev/vgroot/lvusr /usr vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvopt /opt vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvvar /var vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvtmp /tmp vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvhome /home vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvapps /apps vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvsupport /apps/support vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvcrash /var/adm/crash vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvbmc /apps/opt/bmc vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvbest1 /apps/opt/best1 vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvseos /apps/opt/seos vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvopenv /apps/opt/openv vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgroot/lvswapB  ...             swap   defaults  0 0
/dev/vgroot/lvswapC  ...             swap   defaults  0 0

/dev/vgapps/lvHPApache /apps/opt/HPApache vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgapps/lvvarHPApachelogs /apps/opt/var/HPApachelogs vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgapps/lvweblogic /apps/opt/weblogic vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgapps/lvvarweblogic /apps/opt/var/weblogic vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgapps/lvvbroker /apps/opt/vbroker vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgapps/lvoracle /apps/opt/oracle vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgapps/lvsplex /apps/opt/splex vxfs delaylog 0 2
/dev/vgapps/lvvrps /apps/opt/vrps vxfs delaylog 0 2

Hint: Available file system types: hfs nfs cdfs ffs lofs memfs procfs vxfs nfs3 nfs4 autofs cachefs nfs4deleg pipefs dnlc_neg_fs

LVM

The system file layout is configured using the LVM (Logical Volume Manager)

Hint: mkfs -m /dev/vgXX/rlvolYY - displays the command line which created the file system. fsadm -F vxfs /mountpoint to get VxFS details of a filesystem

WARNING: Volume groups may be reported several times, due to use of of Physical Volume Group (/etc/lvmpvg)

VG Group Device Files

ll /dev/*/group|sort -k 6
crw-r-----   1 root       sys         64 0x000000 Oct  6  2009 /dev/vgroot/group
crw-r-----   1 root       sys        128 0x000000 Oct 12  2009 /dev/vgapps/group
crw-r-----   1 root       sys        128 0x001000 Oct 12  2009 /dev/vgshrvr/group
crw-r-----   1 root       sys        128 0x002000 Oct 12  2009 /dev/vgshroravr/group
crw-r-----   1 root       sys        128 0x003000 Oct 12  2009 /dev/vgshroravrbk/group
crw-r-----   1 root       sys        128 0x004000 Oct 12  2009 /dev/vgshroravrstg/group

Physical Volume Group Filter

vgdisplay -v |grep Name | /opt/cfg2html/plugins/pvgfilter.ia64
n/a, error, no output or resource is not configured!

LVM Physical Volume Group Information (/etc/lvmpvg)

cat /etc/lvmpvg
VG      /dev/vgroot
PVG     BOOT_PRI
/dev/disk/disk0_p2
PVG     BOOT_MIR
/dev/disk/disk1_p2

Auto VG Activation (/etc/lvmrc)

grep -v -e ^# -e ^$ /etc/lvmrc
AUTO_VG_ACTIVATE=0
RESYNC="SERIAL"
AUTO_BOOT_MIGRATE=1
custom_vg_activation()
{
        /sbin/vgchange -a y /dev/vgroot
        /sbin/vgchange -a y /dev/vgapps
        # e.g. /sbin/vgchange -a y -s
        #      parallel_vg_sync "/dev/vg00 /dev/vg01"
        #      parallel_vg_sync "/dev/vg02 /dev/vg03"
        return 0
}
parallel_vg_sync()
{
        for VG in $*
        do
                {
                if /sbin/vgsync $VG > /dev/null
                then
                        echo "Resynchronized volume group $VG"
                fi
                } &
        done
}

Boot LVs (lvlnboot)

lvlnboot -v vg00
n/a, error, no output or resource is not configured!

Check the following lines that your mirror (RAID1) is setup properly!

To get the current installed ODE version execute: lifls -l /usr/sbin/diag/lif/updatediaglif2 on 64 bit systems

Boot Device Configuration Table

cat /stand/bootconf|grep -v ^#
l  /dev/disk/disk0_p2

/stand/bootconf should contain all boot devices (mirrored). If not, swinstall may fail after boot from the mirrored disk!

IO Statistics (sar)

sar -d 10 1
HP-UX aavfwp01 B.11.31 U ia64    03/01/12

01:22:15   device   %busy   avque   r+w/s  blks/s  avwait  avserv
01:22:25    disk0    7.21    1.01      21     331    1.84    7.76
            disk1    9.01    3.39      12     265   21.44   26.50

Rule of thumb (baseline): avwait ~ 5 ms, avque ~ 0.5, avserv << 10 ms

Autoport Aggregation

(grep -v -e ^# -e ^$ /etc/rc.config.d/hp_apa*conf);echo LanScan -q:;lanscan -q
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_START_LA_PPA=900
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_INIT_ARGS="HP_APA_LOAD_BALANCE_MODE HP_APA_GROUP_CAPABILITY HP_APA_HOT_STANDBY HP_APA_MANUAL_LA HP_APA_INIT HP_APA_KEY"
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_DEFAULT_PORT_MODE=MANUAL
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_MAX_LINKAGGS=50
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_LACP_SYSTEM_ID_MODE=FIRST_APA_PORT
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_LACP_TIMEOUT=1
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_USE_SYSLOG=1
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_INTERFACE_NAME[0]=lan900   #<-- Note: lan900 will be one of your APA network interfaces
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_LOAD_BALANCE_MODE[0]=LB_MAC
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_GROUP_CAPABILITY[0]=5
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_KEY[0]=900
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_HOT_STANDBY[0]=off
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_MANUAL_LA[0]=0,2  #<-- These last two number are the physical interface card instance number that will be aggregated together
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_INTERFACE_NAME[1]=lan901 #<-- Note: lan901 is your second APA interface
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_LOAD_BALANCE_MODE[1]=LB_MAC
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_GROUP_CAPABILITY[1]=1
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_KEY[1]=901
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_HOT_STANDBY[1]=off
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaconf:HP_APA_MANUAL_LA[1]=1,3  #<-- These are the interface card instances for APA lan901
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_INTERFACE_NAME[0]=lan0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_GROUP_CAPABILITY[0]=5
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_KEY[0]=900
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_PRIORITY[0]=0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_CONFIG_MODE[0]=MANUAL
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_SYSTEM_PRIORITY[0]=0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_INTERFACE_NAME[1]=lan2
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_GROUP_CAPABILITY[1]=5
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_KEY[1]=900
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_PRIORITY[1]=0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_CONFIG_MODE[1]=MANUAL
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_SYSTEM_PRIORITY[1]=0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_INTERFACE_NAME[2]=lan1
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_GROUP_CAPABILITY[2]=1
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_KEY[2]=901
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_PRIORITY[2]=0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_CONFIG_MODE[2]=MANUAL
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_SYSTEM_PRIORITY[2]=0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_INTERFACE_NAME[3]=lan3
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_GROUP_CAPABILITY[3]=1
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_KEY[3]=901
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_PRIORITY[3]=0
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_CONFIG_MODE[3]=MANUAL
/etc/rc.config.d/hp_apaportconf:HP_APAPORT_SYSTEM_PRIORITY[3]=0

Number of TCP/IP Sockets in the same State

netstat -an | grep tcp | awk '{print $6}' | sort | uniq -c
   4 CLOSE_WAIT
  66 ESTABLISHED
  27 FIN_WAIT_2
  48 LISTEN
  16 TIME_WAIT

         N:Reducing max_physical_extents for volume group: vgshroravrbk from

         N:Reducing max_physical_extents for volume group: vgshroravrstg from
         81920 to 2500. The specified value was larger than allowed.
         N:Reducing max_physical_extents for volume group: vgshrvr from 32768
         to 2500. The specified value was larger than allowed.
         
       * Creating New File Systems
       * Creating Mirror of New System Image
       * Copying File Systems To New System Image
       * Making New System Image Bootable
       * Unmounting New System Image Clone
       * System image: "sysimage_001" on disk "/dev/disk/disk2"

=======  02/24/12 06:17:38 EST  END Clone System Image succeeded. (user=root)
         (jobid=aavfwp01)


=======  02/24/12 06:17:40 EST  BEGIN Displaying DRD Clone Image Information
         (user=root)  (jobid=aavfwp01)

         succeeded. (user=root)  (jobid=aavfwp01)

PRM - Resource Process Manager

cat /etc/prmconf; prmlist 2>&1 
# PRM configuration file record formats and syntax rules:
#
# The following lines show the syntax for each record type. Explanations
# of the components are given in the record sections below.
#
# GROUP:{PRMID | HIER}:SHARES:[MAX]:
#
# GROUP:PSET:::[CORES]:[CORE_LIST][:PSET_ATTR]
#
# #!PRM_MEM:{PRMID|GROUP}:SHARES:[MAX]:::[[IMPORT]:[EXPORT]:]
#
# #!SHARED_MEM:{PRMID|GROUP}:MEGABYTES
#
# USER::::INITIAL_GROUP[,ALTERNATE_GROUP[, ...]]
#
# APPLICATION::::GROUP[,{ALTERNATE_NAME[, ...]|'REGEXP'}]
#
# VOLUME:{PRMID | GROUP}:SHARES::
#
# #!SCOMP:COMPARTMENT_NAME:{GROUP | (NONE)}
#
# #!UXGRP:UX_GROUP_NAME:{GROUP | (NONE)}
#
# Text-string processing (of items such as GROUP, ALTERNATE_NAME, and so
# forth) is case-sensitive. These strings cannot include spaces, tabs,
# newlines, colons, commas, or the # character.
#
# For more detailed information on this file, see the prmconf(4) man page.
#
########## FSS PRM group record #####################################
#
# GROUP:{PRMID | HIER}:SHARES:[MAX]:
#
# GROUP
#       FSS PRM group name. For proper display by the ps command, use no
#       more than 7 characters in the PRM group name.
#
# PRMID | HIER
#       Parent nodes in a hierarchy use the HIER keyword, while leaf nodes
#       use PRM group ID. PRMIDs must be unique and can range from 1
#       to 255. PRMID 1 (the default group for users not explicitly
#       assigned to a group) is required.
#
# SHARES
#       CPU shares and, if CPU capping is enabled, the capping value.
#       Share amounts can range from 1 to MAXINT. Shares determine the
#       resource allocation proportions for all children of the same parent.
#
# MAX (Optional) (Default is no per-group CPU limit)
#       Specifies a max (upper bound) for CPU consumption. The max value is
#       expressed as a percent, which is an integer value, ranging from the
#       percentage determined by the group's number of CPU shares to 100.
#       There is no requirement that the per-group max values total 100%.
#       This value is superceded by the minimum percent when CPUCAPON mode
#       is enabled.
#
########## Pset PRM group record ####################################
#
# GROUP:PSET:::[CORES]:[CORE_LIST][:PSET_ATTR]
#
# GROUP
#       Pset PRM group name. For proper display by the ps command, use no
#       more than 7 characters in the PRM group name.
#
# PSET
#       The PSET keyword must be specified for Pset PRM group records.
#
# CORES
#       The number of cores allocated to this Pset PRM group. This value
#       may range from 0 to one less than the maximum number of cores on
#       a system. If blank, the value is determined from the number of
#       cores specified in CORE_LIST.
#
# CORE_LIST
#       Comma separated list of specific core ids to include in the
#       Pset PRM group. If this list is empty then the PRM API will
#       automatically choose the cores to include in the Pset PRM group.
#       If CORES is specified, then CORE_LIST must contain zero core 
#       entries or the number of entries specified by CORES.
#
# PSET_ATTR
#       This optional field passes per-processor set attributes to HPUX. See
#       psrset(1m) -t option for a complete attribute list.  Currently only
#       the logical CPU (Hyper-Threading) feature is integrated with PRM.
#       LCPU=ON means this pset has Hyper-Threads explicitly enabled.
#       LCPU=OFF means this pset has Hyper-Threads explicitly disabled.
#       Psets with no overriding attribute value mimic the default pset.
#
########## PRM memory record ########################################
#
# #!PRM_MEM:{PRMID|GROUP}:SHARES:[MAX]:::[[IMPORT]:[EXPORT]:]
#
# #!PRM_MEM
#       Indicates the start of a Memory record. The # character does not denote
#       the start of a comment in this case.
#
# PRMID | GROUP
#       PRM group ID or group name that corresponds to an existing PRM group.
#       When specifying parents in a PRM group hierarchy or a PRM PSET group,
#       use their names. If Memory records are used, there must be a one-to-one
#       match between PRMIDs in Group and Memory records.
#
# SHARES
#       Specifies the PRM group's guaranteed proportion of available memory.
#       Shares are integer values ranging from one to MAXINT.
#
# MAX (Optional) (Default is no limit)
#       Specifies a max (upper bound) for memory consumption. The max value is
#       expressed as a percent, which is an integer value, ranging from the
#       percentage determined by the group's number of memory shares to 100.
#       There is no requirement that the max values total 100%. You can not
#       specify values for both the MAX and the IMPORT/EXPORT fields.
#
# IMPORT (Optional) (Default is no import limit)
#       Used for memory isolation of a group.  Leave this field blank to
#       disable the memory isolation feature.  Assign the value 0 to both the
#       IMPORT field and the EXPORT field if you would like to isolate a memory
#       critical group to ensure it does not share memory with other groups.
#       The IMPORT field is supported on HP-UX version 11i and above.
#
# EXPORT (Optional) (Default is no export limit)
#       Used for memory isolation of a group.  Leave this field blank to
#       disable the memory isolation feature.  Assign the value 0 to both the
#       IMPORT field and the EXPORT field if you would like to isolate a memory
#       critical group to ensure it does not share memory with other groups.
#       The OTHERS group may never have EXPORT restricted.
#       The EXPORT field is supported on HP-UX version 11i and above.
#
# When specifying memory records for parents in a PRM group hierarchy, you can
# not specify values for the following fields (MAX, IMPORT, EXPORT).
#
########## PRM Shared Memory record ###################################
#
# #!SHARED_MEM:{PRMID|GROUP}:MEGABYTES
#
# #!SHARED_MEM
#       Indicates the start of a Shared Memory record. The # character
#       does not denote the start of a comment in this case. The Shared
#       Memory control feature is supported on HP-UX 11i v2 Update 2 and
#       later.
#
# PRMID | GROUP
#       PRM group ID or group name that corresponds to an existing PRM
#       Memory Group. PRM groups without a Shared Memory record shall
#       default to the PRM_SYS pool for shared memory allocation. Parent
#       groups in a PRM group hierarchy cannot have Shared Memory records.
#
# MEGABYTES
#       The size of the fixed dedicated shared memory pool in megabytes.
#       Every Memory Record, regardless of type, must be assigned at least
#       one megabyte. The maximum value for MEGABYTES is limited by the
#       available megabyte value reported by prmavail minus the minimum
#       amounts for all other Memory and Shared Memory records.
#       This field must be at least 256 memory pages.
#
########## PRM user record ##########################################
#
# USER::::INITIAL_GROUP[,ALTERNATE_GROUP[, ...]]
#
# USER
#       This is either an individual user's login name, or a + character
#       followed by netgroup name. Login names should be found in
#       /etc/passwd. Netgroup names should be associated with a list of
#       login names in /etc/netgroup. At configuration time, any member of this
#       netgroup without an explicit user record will assume the INITIAL and 
#       ALTERNATE groups from this record. 
#
# INITIAL_GROUP
#       Name of user's initial PRM group upon login. The placeholder
#       (NONE) may be used to indicate that no default
#       mapping has been created for this user, while allowing the user
#       to be clearly accounted for in the configuration.
#
# ALTERNATE_GROUP (optional)
#       Name of another group in which this user has permission to run.
#       Group may be changed from the INITIAL_GROUP to ALTERNATE_GROUP
#       by means of prmrun or prmmove commands.
#
# PRM User records other than root cannot contain the PRMID 0 group PRM_SYS.
#
########## PRM application record ###################################
#
# APPLICATION::::GROUP[,ALTERNATE_NAME[, ...]]
# or
# APPLICATION::::GROUP[,'REGEXP']
#
# APPLICATION
#       Full path of the application, starting with a slash (/).
#       The directory name must be fully qualified, but the file name can 
#       include the shell file name wildcard characters *, ?, [, and ].
#       At configuration time, all valid executables matching the expression 
#       without explicit application records of their own will assume the 
#       GROUP of this record.
#
# GROUP
#       Name of the application's assigned PRM group.
#
# ALTERNATE_NAME (optional)
#       Alternate name the application is assigned when executed.
# REGEXP
#       An Extended Regular Expression as defined in regexp(5).
#       Any process whose command line matches the regular expression
#       and which does not have an application record of its own will
#       assume the GROUP of this record.
#
########## PRM disk record ##########################################
#
# VOLUME:{PRMID | GROUP}:SHARES::
#
# VOLUME
#       Full pathname of the desired logical volume beginning with /dev/v
#
# PRMID | GROUP
#       PRM group ID or PRM group name. If Disk records are used for a volume,
#       there must be a one-to-one match between CPU and Disk records.
#
# SHARES
#       Disk shares. Share amounts can range from 0 to MAXINT.
#       Shares determine the resource allocation proportions for all
#       children of the same parent.
#
########## PRM Compartment record ###################################
#
# #!SCOMP:COMPARTMENT_NAME:{GROUP | (NONE)}
#
# COMPARTMENT_NAME
#       The alphanumeric name of a legal active compartment. 
#       It may be between 1 and 256 characters in length.
#       Overrides all other record types for processes in this compartment.
#       There may be at most one such record per compartment.
#
# GROUP | (NONE)
#       Name of the default PRM group for the compartment (if any).
#       When using group hierarchies, you can only assign these records to
#       groups that do not have child groups. The place holder word (NONE) 
#       will create no mapping, but allows all compartments to be clearly
#       accounted for in the configuration.
#
########## PRM Unix group record ###################################
#
# #!UXGRP:UNIX_GROUP_NAME:{GROUP | (NONE)}
#
# UNIX_GROUP_NAME
#       The alphanumeric name of a defined Unix group. 
#       It may be between 1 and 255 characters in length.
#       There may be at most one such record per Unix group.
#       This record will apply if no other record applies to a
#       given process, including User records which do not specify
#       the OTHERS group.
#
# GROUP | (NONE)
#       Name of the default PRM group for the compartment (if any).
#       When using group hierarchies, you can only assign these records to
#       groups that do not have child groups. The place holder word (NONE) 
#       will create no mapping, but allows all Unix groups to be clearly
#       accounted for in the configuration.
#
# PRM Unix group records cannot contain the PRMID 0 group PRM_SYS.
#
OTHERS:1:100::
#
# begin prmloadconf generated user records
#
root::::(PRM_SYS)
daemon::::(NONE)
bin::::(NONE)
sys::::(NONE)
adm::::(NONE)
uucp::::(NONE)
lp::::(NONE)
nuucp::::(NONE)
hpdb::::(NONE)
nobody::::(NONE)
www::::(NONE)
cimsrvr::::(NONE)
tftp::::(NONE)
#
# begin prmloadconf generated unix group records
#
#!UXGRP:root:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:other:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:bin:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:sys:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:adm:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:daemon:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:mail:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:lp:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:tty:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:nuucp:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:users:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:nogroup:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:cimsrvr:(NONE)
#!UXGRP:tftp:(NONE)
#
# prmloadconf execution completed Thu Jul  9 17:23:00 2009
#
prmlist requires that PRM be configured. (PRM-820)

node:aavfwp06|name=aavfwp06
node:aavfwp06|status=up
node:aavfwp06|state=running
node:aavfwp06|initial_incarnation=3
node:aavfwp06|os_status=up
node:aavfwp06|summary=ok
node:aavfwp06|id=2
node:aavfwp06|sg_version=A.11.19.00
node:aavfwp06|sg_patch=PHSS_40583
node:aavfwp06|os_release=B.11.31
node:aavfwp06|cpu_architecture=IA64
node:aavfwp06|boot_timestamp=1304226704
node:aavfwp06|interface:lan900|name=lan900

------ Checking LOCAL network connections (aavfwp01) ------


(The linkloop command will test for link level connections between all LAN
hardware displayed by lanscan. A -- OK after the line means those two 
devices can talk to each other.  A (NO CONNECTION) after a line means
the two devices can not talk at the link (MAC) level. Network connectivity
check will not be performed for non-LAN hardware (HyperFabric, ATM. etc), 
if any, since linkloop command is supported only for LAN hardware.)

------ Checking LOCAL network connections (aavfwp06) ------


(The linkloop command will test for link level connections between all LAN
hardware displayed by lanscan. A -- OK after the line means those two 
devices can talk to each other.  A (NO CONNECTION) after a line means
the two devices can not talk at the link (MAC) level. Network connectivity
check will not be performed for non-LAN hardware (HyperFabric, ATM. etc), 
if any, since linkloop command is supported only for LAN hardware.)

======= /usr/openv/netbackup/bin/bp =======
@(#) NetBackup_6.5.4 1677381802

Contents of file: bp.conf
# BP.CONF - NetBackup Configuration File

# bp.conf now has 50 server options and 39 Client options.
# I thought it best if we started to set them up in categories as we also now
# can in this file.  \# comments out the line as in most shell commands.

#------------------------------------
# Access Configuration
#------------------------------------

SERVER = ebuftwspa01-ebu
SERVER = ebuftwspa11-ebu
SERVER = ebuftwspa12-ebu
SERVER = ebuftwspa01
SERVER = ebuftwspa11
SERVER = ebuftwspa12
MEDIA_SERVER = aavfwp01
MEDIA_SERVER = ebuftwspa01
MEDIA_SERVER = ebuftwspa11
MEDIA_SERVER = ebuftwspa12

#------------------------------------
# Firewall Rules
#------------------------------------


#------------------------------------
# Client Configuration
#------------------------------------

CLIENT_NAME = aavfwp01g

#------------------------------------
# GDM Configuration
#------------------------------------

MASTER_OF_MASTERS = etttvpcm01
KNOWN_MASTER = ebuftwspa01
KNOWN_MASTER = ebuftwspa01

#------------------------------------
# Troubleshooting Log Levels
#------------------------------------

BPSCHED_VERBOSE = 0
BPTM_VERBOSE = 0
VAULT_VERBOSE = 0

#------------------------------------
# Media Server Configuration
#------------------------------------
